ReLife is not your typical Romance School or Time Travel Anime. It is a message. To the current workers in a society hell bent on work culture and to the youthful students going into the real world with bright dreams of what awaits them. 
What grabbed my attention right away was in episode 1, it showed the difference in thinking that 27 year old has compared to a High School-er. What has become Normal to us because of the society around us is still an unfathomable taboo to them in their sheltered years. Case in point: Cigarettes. It was also great to see how theMC's age lets him appreciate many thing we failed to noticed back HS.\n\n
There are many people who might consider ReLife to be a self-insert Travel back in time show. I disagree, unlike those shows, ReLife, doesn't give you a "Forget your troubles" vibe, instead it addresses those troubles and  speaks directly to it's audience about the choice they have and what to do with those troubles. 10/10 for me.

I absolutely enjoyed the show. I don't review much, but I have to say this is one of the few anime I can say this is confidence. Even then I gave it a (9). Nothing's perfect.
Anyhow, story is pretty straight forward, read the summary and you get the just of it, well I mean there's plot twist and all that but the general premise is pretty straightforward.
Art (8) and sound (9) are, while not outstanding, well crafted and chosen, well above average actually. I don't know the ED songs, as I'm not Japanese and cannot understand the actual lyrics, but I'm going to wager aguess and say that they were from the 2000s and maybe the 90s and 80s, to reflect on the nostalgia felt by the MCs.


Characters (10) are very well defined and have immense depth to them. It's often been said that an anime's quality is defined by the quality of its support cast. And this one have a awesome crowd of support cast. That or, there's just a lot of main characters.


This might have something to do with the fact that the anime followed the plot of the manga almost to the letter. But still, well done in character development.


Enjoyment (10) and overall feel (9).. well I'm coming close my 30s myself so I can definitely relate to the general feel of this series...big time. I suppose I just haven't seen an anime like this before, I'm sure there are similar ones out there. But it's not every day you get watch an anime this relatable, despite this also being in a high school setting.


Part of the charm of this anime for me I think, is that it's just so plain - it's got no outrageous plot and battles, or overarching continental/cosmic conflict, there's little sexualization or caricatures. It's just so realistic and so sweet... so.. so sweet it's giving me tooth decay...


But then I've always had a sweet tooth

Would you like to relive your youth? Well, that's just what this anime offers! ReLife takes you back to a high school life full of hardship, romance and everything youth has to offer!
Personally, I didn't have much experience in all high school had to offer (probably because I went and graduated high school at a very young age), but this show depicted the life which I, and many other adults, might have experienced if given the chance to go back again. Now we all have that regret of not doing something at some point in our lives.In truth, there's no going back to that. However,this series promises a better resolution to our dilemma. And this is exactly what the plot of this anime is about.


Arata, the MC, is someone we adults can relate with. Let's face it: the outside world sucks. That's when ReLife comes into his life. He was given another chance to relive his youth, something all of us desire. What makes him more memorable as a character is that we have that characteristic similar to his. I can't name them exactly, but it's there.


The animation was... familiar, at least to me. Then I found out that the series was based off a webcomic. Then it all made sense. It's not everyday you get to see a webcomic get a 23-minute show.


I'd love to write more about this, but perhaps it's better if you give this show a go yourself, and see how it changes you as a person. So let's treasure every moment and enjoy our ReLife!

Life is a bitch. If we get stuck on something in life and we don't know how to deal with it we end up realying on others, and if nobody's around to rely on it turns a pretty significant portion of your life into a big fat turd. Maybe your best friend dies, perhaps a family member passes throws you off the boat as you come out of the closet. At either of these points you may as well shut off your emotions, perhaps double-up by losing faith in your own abilities, or just block all social communication. From there, imagine getting the opportunity torelive one of the most socially active environments in the world: high-school. 


STORY

Relife tells the story of Arata Kaizaki, a 27-year-old man who's given up on finding a job at a company that aspires to something more than creating hearts of ice. Ryou Yoake, an employee at a company that's developed an experimental drug that makes people look 10 years younger. His job is to find adults with shitty lives and help them find their way in a high-school environment to support their progress in finding themselves (and a job) again. It's an interesting premise, and while story covers a lot of authentic subjects we rarely see this well-portrayed it doesn't quite do the characters justice. But the characters have enough traits to maintain interest. 


Characters in anime rarely carry much depth. It's hard to write complex characters and keep an interesting narrative, one of many reasons why Re:Zero -Starting Life in Another World- has seen so much praise, but they don't necessarily make a story. There's more to storytelling than the lines and complexity of different characters, there's also the matter of how well you manage to transfer a level of empathy to the audience. Chances are that, if you haven't experienced a sense of dread or lifelessness you won't like this anime. That's because it's designed for people with those experiences: Students with no ambition other than making a living and hang out with friends; hard workers who lost their passion; emotional zombies; and plenty more. Relife manages to capture the individual moments that lead to losing your way, we witness the student life through the eyes of those who have experienced it. This is supported by a simple but effective animation style.


ART

It can be hard to find enjoyment with certain anime when you take away their unique artstyles. Some anime earn a huge portion of their legacy from their artstyle, but that's not the case here. But considering the obvious budget limitations TMS Entertainment has done a good job of keeping it low-key and efficient. By utilizing style rather than fluid animations they've managed to retain the essence of the emotional states of all characters. Emotions like fear, dread and shame are accompanied by dark colors and hidden eyes. Any lecture on handling life is done in an interrogative, parental manner. Prolonged scenes and silences aren't always as welcome, but for the most part they work pretty well. 


SOUND

Putting aside the music for a moment, there's not much to say about the voice acting either. Every actor fulfill their expected part in this story, but there's often a distinct warmth to the voices. If you were to consider a series like Natsume no Yuujinchou where the main character provides the iconic calm and kind atmosphere, Relife provides a similar atmosphere with a mellow piano and an earnest character gallery. 


CHARACTER

As discussed in the story section of this review, the characters aren't as complex as they could have been. But they do fulfill their roles. Regarding the downward slope, as some may call it, I find that shift in focus came pretty naturally. It was a necessary arc in order to establish how far the other characters had gotten in their personal development. More complex characters come at the expense of sole focus on a single one, and that's what you get towards the second half of this series. 


Unfortunately for this series, the characters have to step aside to allow for the retrospective emotions caused by the observation of events in the classroom. Love and dating are as awkward as you'd expect, but it's all so heavily influenced by the emotions that make us give up on life that you'll likely find yourself either dismissing or accepting this series depending on how well you can emphasize with what happens in the series. Things like romantic relationships seem little more than keys to unlock various topics on hopelessness, dread, detachment, and the like. For someone who's been stuck there for a long time it's a welcome reminder of just exactly what it is we should strive for in life.


ENJOYMENT

Personally, this series holds the key to a lot of flashbacks. But sometimes it's not even a flashback, the issues brought up in Relife are as relevant today as they ever were. Putting together an well-structured story with a slightly prolonged build-up arc it does a stellar job of keeping the viewer coming back for more. I started watching this in the evening and didn't go to sleep until early in the morning, despite having a job to go to. But perhaps that says more about my poor time management habits than the anime itself.

Anyone else in their 20s and having difficulty relating to high school anime? Well don't worry because ReLIFE has found a way to appeal to audiences of ages 15-30.Our protagonist, Kaizaki Arata, is a washed up and jobless 27 year old man who accepts ReLIFE's proposal to become a high schooler again in exchange for paid living expenses and a job upon the experiment's completion in one year. Who wouldn't jump at the chance to repeat high school again by swallowing a magic pill handed to you by a complete stranger? Frankly, the plot of this series is rather unoriginal and definitely overused by othermovies and dramas. BUT, even a simple story can be great if it's executed well and that's definitely the case with this series. 


Characters are in many ways the most important aspect to story telling and ReLIFE does an excellent job at delivering the motivations and personalities behind its characters. What the show lacks in originality, it makes up for in characters, who are in many ways its defining feature. Nearly every story arc (2-3 episodes) applies focus to only one or two characters. As a result, the series effectively provides backstory to individual members of the cast and gradually builds their relationships over the course of the series. Overall, I found most of the characters relatable from the standpoint of a someone living a very normal life. This is partly due to the show's excellent portrayal of everyday issues and a fantastic performance from the voice actors/actresses. 


Personally, I think it's important to go into this series understanding that there is a slice of life tag. In other words, ReLIFE is NOT entirely focused on romance. There are other themes explored in its 13 episodes, such as ambition, confidence, and of course friendship. Other reviews have given this show slightly lower marks mainly due to its rather slow pacing and lack of romance between episodes 7-10. While I can agree that the show might have benefitted from devoting more time to its lead couple, it's only a personal preference and I don't think it's appropriate to fault the studio for including episodes that address other equally important themes. In fact, those episodes add depth to the characters and a measure of realism because normal lives are not only filled with instances of intimacy and romance. 


Finally, we arrive at the anime's greatest fault which is unfortunately its predictability. From episode one, I could tell that even though there was some great writing and surprising sequences, I got the vibe that every scenario was going to be wrapped up nicely and neatly. Admittedly, it was difficult to actually feel sad for any of the characters even when they were struggling because I just knew that things were going to be resolved for them. The bright atmosphere of the show and the optimism of its characters just doesn't allow for prolonged somberness. It's clear to me that the author enjoys happy endings so I never feared for the possibility that certain couples would not end up together. There is also a small mystery concerning the identity of one character throughout the series and when my suspect was revealed, I thought it was every obvious because it resulted in the perfect ending. 


In my honest opinion, ReLIFE is a humble and satisfying addition to anime of school and slice of life genres. Romance is not as prevalent in this show as in others, but it is still substantial and interwoven neatly into sequences of realism. I'd recommend checking this anime out if you enjoy stories that are more balanced in these elements as opposed to overreaching in any single one. Tuck into this anime when you're feeling down and unmotivated because you might just find yourself smiling.

ReLife: If you want a quick fix for a slice of life anime, this'll pretty much do.  
Generally, other than its premise (which you read in ReLife's synopsis) being pretty interesting even if it's not completely original, this anime is pretty average and standard slice of life drama and comedy.  The bulk of the show that doesn't focus on our main character and his ship was a bit slow for me to get through simply because these high schoolers weren't inherently dealing with problems that I cared about.  Most of their problems just made me want them to get over it, butagain, that's just a very slice of life/high school type problem to have, so it's not that bad.  Otherwise, the main character and his ship both go through some fulfilling character development, and the show itself isn't that bad to look at.  


While the animation can get a little stiff at times, it still passes as average.  As for sound, I'm gonna address the soundtrack just because I didn't like it.  It's different in that it's jazzy and strictly keyboard, which is cool and everything, but I didn't like it and it gave me an impression of under-budgeting for the show as a whole.  


As for how much I actually liked it, again, I didn't really like the bulk of the show because it felt like a lot of the show didn't deal with our main character of interest, but the parts that did make him and his ship develop were extremely enjoyable.  Check it out!  It's a nice time killer ^_^


-MSYN

*Spoiler Free
*Enjoyment Rating: 9
ReLIFE overall contained moments that were extremely expected and other moments that were extremely not. Nevertheless, this anime contains several lessons that any age group can relate to on a personal level. Do not be fooled by its chill, laid back, and comedic visuals and atmosphere. But for watchers who would like to watch something chill, laid back, and comedic this anime can still be considered for you -- just expect a little bit of drama.
*Story Rating: 8
As I mentioned already, this anime had moments that watchers could have already expected from simply reading the summary of the anime. The idea ofbeing able to become a high schooler again for a year in of itself an obvious comedic route. However, with the individual being a grown adult and NEET, one can imagine that such a comedic route would contain a sad ending due to the obvious time limit of one year. The grown attachment to individuals that, if you were your actual age, would get you caught in jail. Needless to say, this is where the anime takes a different turn as the main protagonist keeps this fact as a constant reminder when interacting with peers. What was unexpected were the interactions and development that watchers are shown that make this anime more dramatic. 


*Art and Sound Rating: 8


I personally did not find anything unique regarding this anime's art and sound. But I did find character expressions and art style shifts during comedic moments incredibly entertaining. 


*Character Rating: 9


Part of the unexpected moments in this anime had to do with character development. At first glance, each character beyond the protagonist would appear to have static characteristics that would label them as obvious side characters. The cliche character tropes in most anime are all gathered here: the loner, the oblivious one, the try hard, the talented one, the childhood friends, the glasses character, the sadist, etc. As most can be seen as side characters, each character received a fitting amount of screen time and character development that changed these static foil characters into independent and dynamic ones. It is from these characters that watchers are able to find the individual that they are able to relate to personally. Overall, with the variety of characters and situations present in this anime, the watchers will be able to relate to something on some level and accordingly receive an inspirational message as they watch the characters overcome it themselves in the anime. 


*Overall Rating: 9


I personally give this anime an overall rating of 9. The comedic and dramatic genres were executed great. The pinch of romance that all anime watchers secretly want from these characters are given at a satisfying amount as well. Hoping for a season two.

In short: LIFE LESSONS!! 
Don't worry, it's not as boring as it sounds. This anime definitely provides some great life lessons we can follow, and delivered in a beautifully meaningful and balanced way. It never seems like the lecture on life ever overshadows the episode or the plot, but we come away with a basic understanding anyway and a satisfied mind. 
The comic timing was perfect, and as a character, protagonist was stop-notch, even if he was generic-ish. every single character had their own little complicacies and back stories and it was so much fun to watch. I absolutely adored the way they showed agrown up trying to fit into a high school and take and interest in their lives. \n\n
Sub plots were superb!! they had be squealing in delight or groaning in embarrassment or laughing out loud! <3 Music was on point, and i really liked that there were different EDs every time. \n\n
It's a refreshing concept and not too far-fetched, so we are allowed to actually believe what we're being shown. I definitely want to see more of this anime.

Hmm, just binge watched this show and after looking at the reviews I felt like I wanted to give my own opinion, so I thought I'd give my two cents on the show.
I didn't read the manga of reLIFE, in fact I actually turned away from the manga due to small interest in the concept. At first glance the whole process of an older man going to a school with a bunch of young individuals is fairly unappealing. I mean, who wants to see an anime with the romance tag when the protagonist will be several years older than the kids in school? At firstI thought this was pretty disgusting to be honest (lol). Although once you get past the struggle of getting through the synopsis, the show itself exceeded my expectations tremendously I must say.


The story was actually more interesting than I thought it to be. Although it was unappealing to me at first glance, once you start to experience the execution of the story it's much better than it appears to be. I'm sure there are people out there that would appreciate this kind of story regardless of how I was being pushed away from the synopsis, but don't judge this show like I did prematurely. The setting takes place in school which isn't exactly uncommon, although the process to get to the setting is unique. An older man taking a drug to once again turn himself into a high schooler isn't the general process to achieve a school/slice of life anime. Throughout the series ReLIFE the main character is basically interacting with the teenagers, giving advice and help them advance as adults. The point of this show is for development of the main character through the experimentation of sending adults back to their school lives. It's actually enjoyable to watch, as there are plenty of problems with everybody in their lives in high school such as romance, relationships, personal stuggles, and so on. The main character is forced into an environment that he has experienced before, and he helps students solve their problems while also solving his own problems that he has unanswered to in his personal life along the way. 


The art was pretty easy on the eyes. It was easy to look at, although nothing exceptional from the average anime. I did think the colours were done really well though, it kind of brought life and easiness into the show which gave it a relaxation feeling.


The OST/Opening were really well done. I love the opening a lot, it's enjoyable to listen to and really friendly/positive. The endings though, were EXCEPTIONALLY well done. There was a different ending to each episode with different visuals for each ending, and it was extremely enjoyable to listen/watch to considering they took the mood of the episode and basically embodied it into a song. The song choice for the endings were nearly perfect in my books, and I thought it was genius. Like 10/10, they brought plenty emotion to the end of episodes with fairly strong closures on the small arcs of each character. The soundtrack was strong in my eyes. The background music at some particular moments were sometimes a little wonky (didn't feel like the perfect fit for certain particular moments to bring out the emotion in certain scenes) although there was plenty of variety which made it fun nonetheless. 


The characters were the highlights of this anime. I don't want to delve too deep into the characters as they would contain spoilers, although the story is basically highlighting the character development. We get to see and experience the teenagers interacting with the main character and witness the development of the main character AND the other characters simultaneously. The character designs were good and bad at the same time, some characters stood out as unique and interesting, although some characters were just dull and two in particular look extremely similar and it was somewhat hard to tell the difference between the two (Yoake and Ooga).


This show was certainly enjoyable, had strong drama and character development while being enjoyable. The animation wasn't anything special, and the art was decent. Those are the weakest points, although the anime quality is there and I had a fun time with this series. Anime is all about the enjoyment, and I certainly enjoyed ReLIFE =)


Overall, the show had flaws but the pros outshines the cons very well. I think this show is worth the watch, especially if you're looking for an enjoyable comedy/romance/slice of life.

~Spoiler Free~
Being able to fix our mistakes might as well be a dream to strive for. We all have regrets in life no matter who you are and it is up to the individual to work their life around it. Well, ReLife takes the concept by the horns and directs it to a path that is not necessarily different, but interesting.
(Optional)This series is an adaptation of a web comic by the same name and takes on the story of Kaizaki Arata and his life of high school. Funny thing, he is a full grown adult. Acknowledging the fact that life is going downhill due toan unstable job and bad habits, Arata enrolls in the ReLIFE program that gives him the persona of a 17 year old. With this new identity, Arata is then tasked to live one year in this state while attending High school. (Optional)


Now, the story itself is not something to be the determining factor of whether the series is worth to pick it up or not. Keep in mind, this show is a slice of life/school life anime. It follows an ambiguous plot which tends to branch off into sub arcs that are not necessarily relevant to the main conflict of ReLIFE. Although that may not sound very pretty, what drives the anime's story is through character interactions. The plot is more or less a character-driven narrative which is built upon our cast learning more about each other and branch off from there. From then, it depends on whether you, the audience, will find interest in drama that are found through what has been given throughout the series. ~ While the story gets progressively interesting, I will be honest, it is slow. 


With how the anime is presented, the ART and SOUND are both not the greatest and not the worst. The animation is definitely keeping up with its modern day counterparts. It does not necessarily do anything out of the ordinary aside from adding in comedic chibi art (and might I tell you, the anime uses that aspect very well) here and there. Now SOUND is what I want to talk about for a bit. It is unique with how music is used in ReLIFE. Initially looking at this series, I was thinking that modern synthesizers will be used for how I viewed the premise. It was not too serious nor did not give a classic vibe as if the series is taking place way back when. However listening in, it was interesting to hear that a lot of jazzy rhythms that capitalize on piano riffs are what consisted in ReLIFE's bgm. It was weird in a way that kept me interested to see how the music would affect the tone of where the anime is heading towards. 


The CHARACTERS are a very interesting bunch. A bulk of the series is our casts' development, so it will be apparent to the viewers how much they change through their interactions. Personally, Hishiro stood out the most for me due to her portrayal as the "quiet girl".


~~~Personally, I did enjoy the series. It was a wonderful take on the Highschool/SoL genre by adding in an odd aspect. It is definitely interesting to watch and understand our casts' character development. But the way ReLIFE presented itself may not appeal to the general crowd. Some may shy away with how the plot progresses and that is understandable, but it is all for the sake of tying knots together in the end.

[Some spoilers]
ReLIFE was a promising anime. It had an interesting concept and interesting characters. At first glance, I thought this was your generic high school anime but I saw that it had a high 8.21 rating on MAL so I was curious to see how good this actually was. In the end I was somewhat disappointed with the poor execution of what could've been a good anime.
Story 6/10 - The story starts with a man named Arata Kaizaki who then meets Yoake Ryou, a worker in the ReLife Research Institute, programmed to help NEETs...not be...NEETs...basically. Yoake gives him pills and Arata accepts them. Like howI accept ice cream from a guy in a white van.


The next morning he becomes a High Schooler and begins his life in High School again. There he begins helping people because they need helping. He also befriends a couple of friends like Hishiro, Ooga, Onoya, and surprisingly Yoake himself. 


This seemingly good summary changed in the next few episodes however. 2 characters known as Kariu and Honoka suddenly take the spotlight. One of the most one-sided characters i've seen, Kariu is your simple high school tsundere. Okay that might be an exaggeration but seriously, she's fucking stubborn as hell. Excuse my language. Anyways, does this affect the anime positively or negatively? Unfortunately the latter is chosen. 


We get to see how Honoka and Kariu go from best friends to disliking each other then getting back together. And it's all thanks to Kaizaki and Hishiro. 


I have to say I was incredibly disheartened at this. Why didn't they focus on the actual interesting things? I mean I get it's supposed to be "relatable" but when watching this, one word came up to my mind. "Simple." 


Other than that, there were some things I liked. Arata and Hishiro's relationship developing while Arata learning from his previous mistakes when he was actually a high schooler. However, most of the things I remember about ReLIFE is the stupid conflict that could've been solved if Kariu wasn't so stubborn. Basically, the adventure of Arata's problem solving skills.


Character 7/10 -  The characters who got the most screen time were one dimensional. Your tsundere Kariu, Your "big" and clumsy Honoka, and even the emotionless archetype of Hishiro. Although, I like Hishiro's character development. With the help of Arata she overcomes her once previous "loner" nature and becomes more sociable. 


There was also Ooga who is extremely dense but smart. Also the love interest of Kariu. Objectively, he wasn't a bad character but he also one who wasn't really worth noticing except with his conversations with the main lead. 


Ah, don't forget about Onoya and Yoake. They provide the backbone of the anime. Onoya was one of the more interesting characters and Yoake was  as well. Mysterious with that smile of his, you can't really tell what goes in that guy, Yoake's head. In contrast to his personality, Onoya is more laidback and free. This leads to arguments between them with Arata being pulled in as well.


Last of all, there's your "emo kid" Inukai and overly caring Nobunaga. 


So back to the question. There were many good characters so why was Kariu and Honoka in the spotlight? I'm pretty sure that the better characters deserved more development as it looks like both of them didn't really develop at all.


Art 6/10 - This is where ReLIFE failed the most. The art was old for a 2016 anime but in my opinion I liked it. But objectively, there could've been a vast amount of improvement in this category. It wasn't bad but it could've been way better.


Sound 7/10 - I loved the OP and ED. The OP represents ReLIFE with it's bright colors of high school life and depictions of the environment.  As for the ED, there was a bunch of them and as I skipped some of them (unfortunately) I don't have an accurate opinion but I could say that it was decent enough. 


Enjoyment 7/10 - I enjoyed Arata and Hishiro's relationship the most. That was it though. I mean I also liked the others but they weren't as interesting as the 2 of them. I do want to say that the comedy was amazing. It was simple but I laughed and laughed. But that still doesn't make me overlook the once again mentioned conflict. That was what made this a 7 rating. 


Overall 6.8/10 - Overall, this anime is relatable as some reviewers have said but objectively, this had great potential and lost it. Does it live to it's 8.21 rating? I would say no but it was a good watch nonetheless.

- My first ever review -
When I started to watch this, I didn't know what I got myself into. I didn't even know what it was about because I'm the type that watches anything randomly that I might find myself liking or disliking them.
I thought this anime is one of those random, plot-less, nonsense, mundane kind of series that shows the typical day-to-day interaction between each characters, but I was definitely wrong. Very wrong. This anime is way deeper than I thought it would be. To be honest, it is hard to find anime that has story that I can relate too. The last timeI ever felt like this is when I was watching AnoHana and Clannad and that was quite a while ago.


Watching each episodes really got me thinking about my life, mainly because I feel like a failure myself. I'm 20 years old but I don't really have the drive to continue on living anymore. Everyday I'd think to myself, "What's the point?". Despite all that, I'd still wake up each day even though I don't know what to do. I'd just go with the flow, accepting whatever that comes to me, but that made me feel very much like an empty vessel.


Then, I encountered this anime today. That encounter feels like fate or something. It was life-changing, if I'm being honest. I saw myself in the character 'Hishiro Chizuru'. She is exactly like me. I can totally relate when she said the words, "My heart grew numb". 


The interaction between each characters and how they grew is really fascinating and very heartwarming. It is interesting how events are triggered when the characters decided to take action or not. It does make you question about the 'what-ifs' in life, what will happen if you decided to do this or what will happen if you decided not to do it. This anime is so real. It touches the issues that I'm sure most people are thinking about, although some might only do it in their subconscious mind.


Here is my rating~


Story: 10/10 (Outstanding)

The story might seem mundane and typical but it is very deep and special (Personally, super special to me) in its own way. I know that I have said this before but it is rare to find such a heartfelt story that I can't help but focus to it. The story is very thought-provoking too, really made me think about life and the people around me a lot. 


Art: 10/10 (Outstanding)

To be honest, the art is not that special. It look like most typical anime out there (although the 3 horizontal lines eyebrows on the characters 'Tamarai' and 'Asaji' caught my attention because I have never seen that before). The reason why I gave it a 10 out of 10 is because the simplicity of the art allows the story to shine more and I think that it is really, really great. 


Sound: 6/10 (Fair)

I actually didn't pay much attention to the sound used in the anime but every time they came on, the sounds used were very appropriate for each important moments in each episodes. They don't have much impact but they do fit the moments very well.


Character: 10/10 (Outstanding)

The characters in this anime is very well-made and it is nice how they are not rushed or anything. They grew when they are meant to grow and that is fantastic. Each of them have their own unique selves and the way they interact with each other is always interesting. 


Enjoyment: 10/10 (Outstanding)

Overall, I really, really enjoyed watching this anime. It is so interesting that I watched the whole anime in one sitting. That is how interesting it is. I am so glad that I came across this anime. I laughed and cried as I watched it and is always curious of what is going to happen in the next episode.


Please give this anime a chance. You will not regret it. :)

As a working adult (this probably doesn't apply to some of you), do you ever regret how you spent your adolescent years? Kaizaki is twenty-seven years old yet has low self-esteem and literally no future after his parents decide to cut chipping in for his rent. Luckily, he is chosen as a human experiment for Relife, a one-year long second chance at adolescence (and which will cover his living costs).
I absolutely love shows where people are introduced into new situations (Kuromukuro, and FMP being strong examples) and this fits the bill quite well. In this case, Kaizaki has a ton more life experience than hispeers and so he is able to help others around him while simultaneously healing some of his own personal anguish. It's a very well thought out concept and likewise well executed. For those looking for a slightly more mature taste in their anime (no I don't mean hentai), look no further.


[b]Animation:[/b]

The animation in Relife isn't anything particularly special, if anything I'm actually surprised that a fair number of school backgrounds are drawn rather than generated. The show has a light atmosphere overall with bright, fairly saturated coloring. The characters have an average level of detail though they do a pretty good job of aging Kaizaki and Yoake. The characters are fairly standard overall though there are many scenes where characters are drawn as humorous and occasionally cute chibi caricatures. Hishiro's smile is definitely one thing that never gets old. There isn't any action and this is isn't an ecchi-based show.


[b]Sound:[/b]

The show opens with a decent piece with a good main melody but more interestingly, ends with a different ED in every episode. These EDs are all hits in Japan from the late 90s or early 2000s; fittingly, these pieces should resonate with Japanese viewers in Kaizaki's age range. For us culturally deprived foreigners, Natsumatsuri in episode 12 will probably be the most recognizable tune as the ED from Watamote. The BGM in the show is very minimalist, most of which is just a sole piano; though simple, some of the melodies will become familiar by the end of the show.


The show has a lot of star VA power. Our protagonist is supported by Ai Kayano playing a extremely smart yet socially awkward Hishiro, Haruka Tomatsu playing a humorously tsundere Kariu and up and coming Reina Ueda as the supportive fellow transfer student Onoya. This show is mostly dialogue driven and they do a great job keeping things interesting.


[b]Story:[/b]

Kaizaki takes a magic pill to enter the Matrix er... to make him look like a teenager and re-enrolls in high school. There he befriends those sitting around him and eventually helps them resolve interpersonal issues. The story is a mix of hilarious comedy and really good character development. It flows like a slice of life and is pretty light most of the time. There's one central plot line following Kaizaki's new daily life, there isn't any particular rising action or climax though for me the last few episodes were particularly enjoyable.


Though this sounds really light and fluffy, underneath the hood it's a human experiment to try to rehabilitate NEETs. And though I won't spoil exactly what it is, there's a pretty good twist at the very end of the show. It's a great watch overall, especially for us older viewers, and ends on a pretty positive note.


[b]Character:[/b]

If you like exploratory character relations, this show is gold. Placing someone who's mentally older than their teacher is hilarious, and seeing how he has to readjust to cultural norms for those a decade younger are likewise comically explored. There are a lot of interpersonal issues between characters in the show, many of them surrounding Hishiro, who initially doesn't get along with anyone despite being the smartest brain in the cast, and Kariu, whose tsundere shield ends up offending and hurting multiple people. There is a lot of growth in the characters throughout the show, and the last few episodes are particularly exciting for those who like reliving the hatsukoi experience. The cast is relatively small, and just enough exposition is given to supporting characters to keep the focus on the central protagonists.


[b]Value:[/b]

Though the story isn't as engaging as ReZero, this show has a vibrant, playful personality and makes up the difference through outstanding characters. I found myself rooting for the protagonist at one moment only to start laughing uncontrollably the very next scene as a result of Hishiro's innocent antics. This was an absolute pleasure to watch and, due to the late plot twist, definitely has re-watch value. If you're tired of the fantasy genre and or overly moe characters, this show has a compelling package.

I should start by pointing out that there is a very clear target audience for this type of show; a more mature demographic will relate more to the main character(s) and understand most of the content than other (younger) demographics will. The concept of being able to go back and redo high school with all of your knowledge and experience in tact can seem like a very romantic one to those who've graduated from it; and even more so for those who have not necessarily been too successful after-the-fact. Whilst not necessarily being something that crosses the mind of someone still in it as it'sthen not a retrospective.


So for me there is some obvious bias here as I not only relate through the age range of the characters as a late 20 something (the fact that the show does target this age range is in itself refreshing), but I also relate to the main character perhaps a little too acutely regarding their personal hurdles as well. Partialness aside, what is endearing about the show and what I feel gives the show some real integrity (if not quality) is the fact that the show doesn't stray too far from reality, magical age pill that can also conveniently erase memories notwithstanding, a lot of high school based anime's can be quite abstract from the mostly subtle (Lovely Complex, ToraDora!) to the most extreme (Kill la Kill, Assassination Classroom). The character designs are quite conservative (no overtly bright hair) and the character personalities are generally not that eccentric (obligatory exception to the rule being Hirisho).


The art does leave a little to be desired, it is by no means the best, it might even be a little disappointing when compared to its contemporaries as there is a lot of really refined stuff being released these days, but the show is still easy on the eyes as i'm mostly comparing it to above average shows setting a high bar here. I suppose this is my roundabout way of saying that it's average in aesthetics.


There's nothing wrong with the sound either (per sé), though in one or two episodes the piano based mood music was a tad strong/melodramatic which jolts your suspended disbelief briefly.


But really it's just a nice, tidy, neat show in which most obstacles are overcome quickly and concisely giving the story an enjoyable pace and though this isn't relevant months after publication, the fact the shows first season was released entirely in one go was perfect for people who like to marathon content.

There isn't one specific element that makes this series great, but everything combined is what puts it over the top. The characters are well developed and likable. The plot is also well developed and intriguing, while the animation is solid and looks good. All of these elements intertwined, along with a touch of nostalgia and an extremely relatable plot, make this anime great. Anyone who has already graduated high school and entered the real world will become entranced in the series immediately. During every situation I can sit back with a smile and say "Yep I remember those days." Anyone who wants an anime thatcan be related to their own life should look no further than here. ReLIFE provides lots of entertainment, laughs, and love. You don't want to miss this one!

I really enjoyed ReLIFE!
Keywords: Slice of life, Romance
The story touches on social interactions and self-worth. The message it wants to deliver is presented in a mature way since the main protagonist is a 28-year-old adult. Regardless of your age, you'll still be able to follow the story easily with all the comical interactions btw characters. Though the existence of this organization and experiment is unrealistic but the story and characters are all interesting. It has a bittersweet ending.
PROS
+ Great approach to a real-life problem, making it relatable for some.
+ Good pacing
+ The message is delivered splendidly (Pick yourself up from failure)
+ Good balance of maleand female characters\n
+ No harem just friends\n\n
CONS\n
- Main protagonist still smokes cigarettes after \n
- Technical issues unanswered (What's their organization & How memories are removed)\n\n
There's a continuation of the story in ReLIFE: Kanketsu-hen. The last episode made me tear a bit...\n\n
[SPOILER ALERT]\n
It's a bit sad that they didn't show how their 'high school friends' life is like after the experiment ended. \n\n
[ATTENTION]\n
If you still have lingering feelings after watching ReLIFE anime, do check out the last few chapters in ReLIFE manga. It will help provide closure by showing you events that happened after the ending. Do note certain scenes may be different but the message is the same.

I'll admit, I'm not in my twenties. But I'm an adult so that gives me a pass to feel good about this anime right? Ahahaha but seriously it's a good anime, the story was really interesting and the characters had good stories.
But there was one thing that I didn't like, 3/4 through the series, I feel like the anime became clouded in filler, I feel like the start of the anime and the relationship between the two characters just vanished because the writers forgot to talk about the other characters. Long story short, I felt like a few episodes were rushed and some relationships wererushed. 


But other than that, It was really good! The ending off the anime was really good, even better when the ovas actually continue the story! So not going to spoil anything but keep an open mind when you finish the first season, because the ovas are great!


There are some scenes from the manga which I feel like should have been shown in the ovas so I suggest starting from chapter 220 in the manga after you finish the ovas. But the ovas make a good ending anyway but just feels like there is more to the story, WHICH THERE IS! 


The art was good, nothing crazy good. Just good. If you're looking for a chill anime about romance but guys will like, go check this out! This anime has a lot off funny moments which remind me off awkward things back when I was in High School and it really does make you appreciate those times. It's a good show but I hope maybe a season two comes along with new material, I think the ending off the manga really sets up a whole new story!

If you had a chance to relive your youth, would you take it? 
The story follows Kaizaki Arata, an unemployed 27-years-old man who is given that chance. After accepting it and taking a pill his body is now that of a 17-years-old adolescent and he must attend highschool again for a year.
This anime is kind of a "deconstruction" of teenage social relationships, mixing that with SOL and a bit of romance-comedy, with the addition that in the cast of youthful adolescents full of energy and love to give there is a grown up dude in the body of a teenager who sometimes acts like thevoice of experience, trying to relive his youth at his fullest and making his new friends enjoy their youth while they still can, though not making their lives simpler.


Somehow I feel that this anime falls into the same category of Kokoro Connect. ReLIFE explores those relationships from the point of view of a 27-years-old man. The basis for the plot of ReLIFE (the pill and stuff) are rather incredible (as seen in Detective Conan) but it never affects the unraveling of the story. It has its tedious moments of slowness and repetitiveness that I feel are important to get more in touch with the characters, but overall it's fairly good.


Characters are rather cliché (but honestly where do you see characters in a school based SOL that aren't cliché), you have the silent girl, the tomboyish-girl, the laid-back boy, et cetera. Character development is really slow at the start of the series in my opinion and feels very rushed when it actually happens. At some point the development is stationary (the tedious part I mentioned earlier), when the series focuses on the past of some characters. There are little to no interventions of background characters or even side characters that are important for like a half of an episode though. In any case, again, this doesn't affect the unraveling of the plot towards the ending.


The design of the characters is very solid, they never lose their shape nor feel off while out of focus. Somehow the drawing and their reactions feel exaggerated like those of an anime of the past decade (you know, very "anime-ish") and I personally feel that it's pretty nice (sometimes I miss them watching new shows). The backgrounds aren't tough but simple, and visually the series is very pleasant to watch. Voice acting has nothing much remarkable in my opinion, as it's well done but in some few moments the tone of the voice feels uncompatible with the expressions of the character. Talking about the soundtrack I really liked those eccentric piano passages that are played in tension moments, and the rest of the soundtrack fits the atmosphere of a SOL but is not memorable at all, mostly because the whole soundtrack is rather absent for the majority of the series.


In any case this is a fun and pleasant series to watch, besides everything I really enjoyed the series. The jokes are ok, the drama is nice and the plot is easy to follow along. I highly recommend it if you like SOL with a bit of insight in social relationships.


I would like to have watched this series when I was in high school.

A Christian's Anime Review
ReLIFE
Discernment Topics
Violence: \/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
Some mild slapstick occurs occasionally.
Some people sustain sports related injuries. Nothing is graphic.
Language:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
Mild language throughout.
Several cases of moderate language. Nothing too offensive.
Spiritual Content:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
None that I could discern.
Fanservice/Sexual Content/Nudity:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
While the premise may seem like the perfect set-up for some creepy-weirdness, the show remains remarkably tame. No overt fanservice was present and only brief, very minor things could be quantified as fanservice.
The main character does, however, frequently remind himself that the situation he is in, that of hanging out with high-schoolers (girls included), could be potentially illegal in some situations. He is also jokingly reminded by his handlers to not "jump" girlsthat visit his apartment.\n
Some characters joke about getting a girlfriend. One adult character briefly begins describing an illicit situation before getting cut off.\n
One song has some suggestive lyrics.\n\n
Misc. Suggestive Content:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
The whole premise begins with the main character receiving and consuming a pill given to him by a stranger... needless to say, this is not the best example. In general, I suppose, the main character isn't supposed to be a good example for the first part of this show. Does that bother someone? Well sheesh, then why don't you just go watch a show about perfect people who never do anything wrong... oh wait... that would be boring.\n
Also, literal stalking is a job some characters hold. Complete with elaborate layers of deceit, counterfeit, and corporate support.\n\n
Detached Assessment\n\n
Story:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
8/10\n
The story remained entertaining throughout and managed to sell it's comedy and drama well. Situations were generally believable aside from the wonky initial premise.\n
I feel like the story could have done with a slightly more drawn out conclusion, but it was still good.\n\n
Characters:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
9/10\n
All of the characters were very well done in my opinion. Some were exceptionally well done to the point were you could almost cringe with how real they seemed. Sometimes the motivations people have in real life aren't pretty, just messy and visceral.\n\n
Art:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
8/10\n
The show was based of a web comic, so the art style is somewhat simplistic. Not bad by any means though. It does a good job and never feels too much or too little... except when the crowds get partially (???) replaced by silhouettes in the last episodes.\n
The show often cuts into a comedic chibi art-style during certain jokes and stuff. However, it is these parts that end up being more stylized than you'd expect and it's great.\n\n
Sound:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
9/10\n
The OP is good.\n
There is a different ED for EVERY SINGLE episode. I'm not even kidding. Some of these EDs are absolutely amazing, others are very unique and definitely noteworthy, some are just good.\n
OST fits and doesn't cause any problems.\n\n
Enjoyment:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\n
8/10\n
The pacing kept the hijinks and drama rolling at equal paces. I could easily sit down and watch six of the episodes at a time.\n
Not once was I bored with the way things were going, it was all quite well done.\n\n
Conclusion\n
If you're looking for a good high-school comedy/drama with some light romance and almost no fanservice, this is the show for you.\n
I can't really think of a reason why someone shouldn't watch this show, it's very good with almost no drawbacks for what it is.

Tired of over-powered Shounen characters screaming 247 whilst blasting away at anything that moves? Sick of disproportioned hentais shoving unrealistic imouto and harem themes down your throat?? Do you want a welcome change of pace?? Re:Life is your answer
Re:Life answers the one question everybody encounters at some point in their lives: What if i could have done things differently??
Our story follows a principled and hard-working 27 year old Arata Kaizaki, who wonders mysteriously upon one Ryo Yoake, whom subsequently offers Kaizaki the  opportunity for a Re:life. The opportunity to take a specially developed pill which returns his features to that of a high schoolstudent. Kaizaki will then return to high school for the year where his interactions, friendships, love interests and educational studies will all be monitored and finalised in a report at the end of the year.


The drama and comedic elements stem from the fact that Kaizaki whilst having the features of a high school student, will still have the memories, experience and physique of a non-physical 27 year old and therefore will have to be very careful when interacting with others, so as not to give away any information which could unfurl his little secret. 


In my opinion this is a very well paced anime, the music fits the anime and scenes very well and furthermore the animation style is very crisp and accentuates the often comedic humor almost perfectly. 


Much of the criticism stems from unfair comparisons with the Light Novel, the detail (in particular in the OVA's Kanketsu-Hen) has been methodically trimmed in order to compensate for the 13 short episodes and 4 short OVA's. However for non-LN readers this is largely unnoticeable as the information within the story provided is more than enough to not cause any issues, in particular the visual hints provided within the OVA's provides a great conclusion (not to mention how brilliant the ending scene was). As they say a picture speaks a thousand words and this is utilised to great effect throughout the show.


If you haven't seen RE:Life and your able to delve into shows completely open-minded (in particular you LN readers) then you won't be disappointed. You'll laugh, cry and be emotionally connected with Arata and his friends (in particular Hishiro-San) and end up completely satisfied by the end of the OVA (a must watch 4 episode OVA if you watch the 13 episode anime).

I think most young people (teens and early 20s) will not get much out of this anime.  It is still a pretty typical, enjoyable Japanese high school drama though.
However, I believe you will only understand what it means if you are over 35 and completely moved out of your high school/ university environment.
There is a part of the starting credit where the main character is surrounded by his high school classmate and they all jump, then he lands on his feet all by himself. Well, that's pretty much sums it up, that's how life goes in general, one moment you are with your friendsand family, and then it just feels like you jumped and suddenly they are all gone... and it just feels like there are a million ways you could have made things better and a million things which you could have done...

I would not hesitate recommending ReLIFE to anyone who's looking for a short, fun romance anime. Here's a short review to explain why.
Plot:
The concept of the show was well-executed. The main protagonist (an adult in a high schooler's body) who was planning to keep a low profile in the beginning eventually delved into the high school shenanigans. 
His adult insight provided a fresh perspective on the ordinary rom-com scenarios. At times it would be mature and constructive, but at times it would reflect his pessimistic take on life, which is later on greatly influenced by his new teen friends.
Characters:
The show does a good job developingthe distinct characters in the story. Even besides the two main protagonists, the supporting characters had their own dilemmas and arcs which kept them relevant and interesting. \n\n
P.S. It's also a fun anime that has gags to keep you entertained throughout the show, and the ending is a shocker :)

Let me say, this is my first review and I had to write it because this anime was that good. 
The story:
I love how this anime it not quite like the others. It has to deal with how difficult adult life can be and how many of us wish that there was a chance to go back into the past and try to fix things. It truly makes you reflect on your own life and how you could have done things differently.  It is filled with so many different emotions and surprises that literally make you speechless.
The art:
I am quite the fan of themore modern art style so this is right up my ally and anyone else's who likes this type. I just love the little expression the characters make.\n\n
The sound:\n
This usually isn't that important to me. I really enjoyed listening to the intro over and over. It is so lightweight and very relaxing.\n\n
The character:\n
Oh my, I have no idea where to start. There is just so much character development in just these 13 episodes. You really get to see each character and how they change over time. You begin to just fall in love with these characters and want what is best for them.\n\n
The enjoyment:\n
I stayed up until 4am to complete the whole series. I even missed my morning class that next day. I just could not stop watching it. After each episode, you just want to continue and find out what happens next.\n\n
Overall:\n
My favorite thing about this is how well it goes with the manga. I have read up to chapter 151, impatiently waiting for the next ones to come out. I didn't expect the anime to be as good because....well they usually aren't. When I started watching the anime I was so shocked by how well it copied the manga, even the character design and faces and everything! This has become one of my favorite anime for sure!

The causal effect of our actions are very complex and in totality,very hard to decipher.However,what if those actions affected only you? What if there was no one to remember what you did? On the one hand: you could break all rules,steal,be promiscuous,etc.If no one is going to remember me,all this will be inconsequential after a while.It's the easier way out.However,this simulation can also be a road to get to know yourself better.To understand new people,gain new experiences and be a stimulated and totally different person when the simulation ends.ReLife deals with the latter possibility.
Kaizaki Arata is a directionless,jobless person who seems to have no friends.Heis drunk and returning back home alone when a stranger offers him a 'ReLife': For 1 year,all his expenses will be paid for.In exchange,he will be a part of a simulation where his appearance will be that of a teenager in high school,but he will have all memories of his present life.The stranger will be his support for this duration.Post this 1 year,he will be the same old self but with new memories and hopefully,new mindset.


I had very low expectations from this show.So,I was pleasantly surprised at how fun it was.The humor flowed naturally and the characters were well chalked out.Almost every episode revealed a new facet of a character or about the relationship between characters.We also learn about Kaizaki's backstory.During all this while,it stays an entertaining show.Inspite of his reservations,the central character cannot hold back his actionable nature.He influences the lives of students around him.Inspite of knowing that all his actions will eventually have no effect and no memory in peoples' minds,Kaizaki continues to be a positive influence.Thus,performing one of the most selfless acts an individual can do: Doing good not only without reward,but also without any relationship or any good publicity to gain.However,the last few episodes seem to take a tonal shift.The writers decide to play against their strengths and it dampens the flow of the anime.Not that the episodes are bad,but they just...seem off.Also,the twist towards the end does little to add to the show.It's predictable and a tad unnecessary imho.


Still I liked the central idea of the show and the message it conveys.Definitely a one-time watch.

It connects to me and has help me realized that I myself have watched allthese type of genre anime about restoring life such as Clannad, Angel beats, Plastic memories, Erased where the MC is hopeless and depressed or just no good at life until he meets or reunites with someone from their past. i must be honest i just recently got into anime when i moved out two years ago. I was depressed and in state where i was unstable like the girl I fell in love with in high school, I tried anime then and it never appealed to me, but somehow now I'm obsessed with Japanese culture, and anime. This anime and many others like these have made my mind click that the reason i watch anime is to lift myself a tad when i remember her, when i remember that there might be that little bit of hope of reuniting with her, where this time there will be more to talk because i now know more. This anime will speak to the ones who had someone in their lives they wish to reunite with, this anime will appeal to ones who feel they've reached a point of life where it's all just a weekly cycle of the same events, get up, work, anime, sleep, and reset. This anime is a ten in story because it's the story we want, the story we hope for, to have a second chance, meet new people, and or reconnect with someone who we haven't talked to in a long time. But trust me if you're anything like me the end will make you cry, just thinking About it now i am starting to jerk a few tears. That's it, I'm going to go re-watch the end now.

Wow.. Just.. Just wow! I know my scores are normally high for every anime but this one was amazing.. SPOILERS AHEAD.. duh..
Story 10/10: At first, I skipped over this anime because I didn't think it appealed to me from what I had read and I thought the ending was bad so I normally skip over the sad ending ones.. But onwards! I don't think I've really come across a anime with such an original story like this yet and it will definitely leave a memory in the back of my mind to a point where I'll go "Wow, I remember that anime! Ima go re-watchit!" So.. The story is amazing, but the only thing I had a moment of thought about was the science part of the show and I'm probably thinking to much about it but I'm sort of second guessing how the whole mind erasing, 10 years younger stuff works?.. Maybe it's just me but eh! I did however like how it all came together, I already knew that Hishiro was a test subject and a few others thing because It's just what I do.. I spoil the anime for myself because I don't like things I don't know and I have the control to know what will happen.. Just how I am?.. The ending was sweet and romantic and I really loved how it went, kind of stupid how they both chose ReLife to work and the company was like "Damn nothing can go wrong here can it?" but it was cute and innocent so I'll forgive them! I'm salty on how they erased everyone's memories but as long as they got together in the end I don't really care. It was also really nice to see that they took shut-ins, depressed people who are actually caring to give them a chance at a 'ReLife' and it is a really nice watch from a viewers point! I did feel like the romance was abit rushed towards the end but I still really enjoyed it!


Art 9/10: Art was really nice, none of that arm waving stuff when they get embarrassed or they run off at 200mph.. There wasn't many sad/romantic scenes but the ones we got was really nice and sweet! Nothing I can really claim that was bad for the animation but it wasn't perfect aswell..


Sound 8/10: I honestly don't care much for sound/music in anime and maybe this is because I'm more focused on reading subs or listening to dubs.. but as long as it sounds good I don't really care and nothing really seemed out of place!


Character 9/10: Characters were amazing, even the supporting ones! It was really nice to see how they came together and it was nice they used people who were having trouble with their life's to do the experiment and it was really nice to see both the main characters come together in the end. Supporting characters were fairly decent and had a decent about of weigh in on the rest of the story. They weren't overly used to a point where it came annoying or to a point where you'd hate them but it was really nice seeing them give a push sometimes!


Overall: The anime is really nice, sweet and innocent! It's a good romance story along with a mysterious side to it sometimes. It's not overly romantic to a point where it's fully focused on romance but it's not never used.. it's a good amount and i appreciate that. I highly recommend this to someone who loves romance and love all the soppy crap that comes with them!
